text.p: Recall that [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}_1[/mathjaxinline] is the space of polynomials of degree at most one. Use the inner product [mathjaxinline]\langle f, g \rangle = \int _0^1 f(t)g(t) \ dt.[/mathjaxinline]

The polynomial [mathjaxinline]f(t) = 1[/mathjaxinline] has norm 1 under this inner product. Find a polynomial [mathjaxinline]g \in \mathbb {P}_1[/mathjaxinline] such that [mathjaxinline]\{ f; g\}[/mathjaxinline] forms an orthonormal basis of [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}_1[/mathjaxinline].
There are multiple possibilities for the linear function [mathjaxinline]g[/mathjaxinline]; enter one that has a positive slope.
Remember to type * for multiplication. You can type sqrt(3) for [mathjaxinline]\sqrt {3}[/mathjaxinline].

font.p: The list [mathjaxinline]\{ 1; t\}[/mathjaxinline] forms a basis of [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}_1[/mathjaxinline]. It isn't orthonormal, however. To find an orthogonal basis, we can use Gram-Schmidt. Projecting [mathjaxinline]t[/mathjaxinline] onto the span of 1 gives [mathjaxinline]\frac{\langle t, 1\rangle }{\langle 1, 1\rangle } 1 = \int _0^1 t \ dt = \frac{1}{2},[/mathjaxinline] so [mathjaxinline]t-\frac{1}{2}[/mathjaxinline] is orthogonal to 1.
However, it does not have norm 1. We can calculate that

so the norm of [mathjaxinline]t-\frac{1}{2}[/mathjaxinline] is [mathjaxinline]\frac{1}{\sqrt {6}}[/mathjaxinline]. Thus, multiplying by [mathjaxinline]\sqrt {6}[/mathjaxinline] then gives us something with norm 1.
